questions.question_text: A security administrator wants to implement the ability to prevent an unauthorized user from tailgating into the office building. Which of the following should be implemented?

comments.content: Mantraps are in the Network+ objectives, it's even on the A+.
This is Network + and Security + . Its list in the objectives

discussion.content: This is another security plus question not a network plus question

questions.question_text: Joe, a technician, was able to copy data at a site with no network equipment between two new laptops, featuring gigabit Ethernet ports, by using a regular straight- through patch cable. Joe then unsuccessfully tried to accomplish the same thing at a different site from his laptop with a gigabit Ethernet port to an older customer unit, which had a 10/100 network port. Which of the following is the cause of this?

discussion.content: Based on the wording of this question I believe the answer should be B. Copying from "two new laptops" assumes that neither one are Joe's laptop.

comments.content: buddy it tells you that the three laptops have gigabit ethernet ports but the customer's laptop doesn't. you have to read the question.

choices.B: Joe's laptop does not support auto-MDIX.
choices.D: The customer's laptop NIC does not support full duplex.
choices.A: The customer's laptop does not support auto-MDIX.
choices.C: Straight-through patch cables are prone to crosstalk.

comments.content: Nice link. Good quality info there. Thanks.

However, the theory is different from what will happen on most networks today that have VLAN-aware Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) running.

For example, on Cisco switches with CDP enabled, CDP will detect that the native VLANs are mismatched:

vlan mismatch

Secondly, STP will block that port on the affected VLANs:

correct answer should be A. BPDU guard.
untagged ports = access port
when we connect any switch to access port that is configured with BPDU-guard. it will error disable the port when it received BPDU from switch.
A, B and D are relative to a redundant network implemented through STP. Flood Guard purpose is to block access just based on the MAC Address available on the new access: I would answer C
The answer given is wrong. BPDU guard is the correct one.

comments.content: BPDU is a feature of STP

discussion.content: Any ideas why it couldn't be A?

questions.question_text: Which of the following would block access to an untagged port when connected to a Layer 2 device?
Which of the following OSI layers contains the LLC function?

discussion.content: In the IEEE 802 reference model of computer networking, the logical link control (LLC) data communication protocol layer is the upper sublayer of the data link layer (layer 2) of the seven-layer OSI model.

comments.content: LLC and MAC addresses are in layer 2. LLC Logical Link Control is the interface between MAC sublayer and layer 3.
No. MAC and LLC work together on Layer 2.

No. The aspect of the NIC that talks to the operating system, places outbound data coming “down” from the upper layers of software into frames, and creates the FCS on each frame. The LLC also deals with incoming frames by processing those addressed to the NIC and erasing ones addressed to other machines on the network.

discussion.content: I think LLC and IPwork on layer 3 please correct ne ?

The answer should be A
RADIUS is a protocol that allows for centralized authentication, authorization, and accounting
(AAA) for user and/or network access control. RADIUS clients contact the server with user
credentials as part of a RADIUS Access-Request message, and the server responds back with a
RADIUS Access-Accept, Access-Reject, or Access-Challenge message

comments.content:
No. RADIUS typically sends config information back to the client. RADIUS carries authentication from a Network Access Server (NAS) to a AAA server. When the authentication request is sent to a AAA server, the AAA client expects to have the
authorization result (config) sent back in reply

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security-vpn/remote-authentication-dial-user-service-radius/12433-32.html
Although password is sent, the main functionality is telling the NAS what to do with that client.

discussion.content: D. is the BEST answer for this question.

I believe the answer should be A as the primary function of a RADIUS server is to authenticate users and maintain user profiles in a database. Please if I am wrong correct me but not sure how this is not the correct answer

questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST describes the RADIUS authentication service protocol?

choices.C: A protocol that sends X.500 service requests to the authentication server
choices.D: A protocol that sends configuration information from the authentication server
choices.B: A protocol that sends encrypted tickets from the authentication server
choices.A: A protocol that sends passwords to the authentication server
